A ASSET TOWARDS 
GOING BEYOND STANDARD ANALYSIS
EMMANUEL PETIT209John Dewey’s pragmatism, and in particular his analysis of the importance of rules and habits in individual behavior, is generally known to many economists because of the influence he had on institutionalist authors. Throughout his career, Dewey also contributed to the development of a rich and complex theory of emotions. In this article, we show how John Dewey’s philosophy is likely to contribute to the introduction of a process – emotion – into a discipline that immediately assumes a very high level of rationality in behavior. Dewey’s transactional approach 
identifies the limits of a behavioral economics of emotions, the foundations of 
which are still largely based on the psychology of emotions.

of emotion is an asset in going beyond standard economic analysis. By 
going beyond the functionalist approach to emotion and 
situating it at the interface (in a transaction process) 
between the individual and his environment, Dewey gives it a major role in the intellectual 
process that leads to choice. Far from being a “bias” – an alteration 
of reason as standard economic analysis presupposes – emotion in the pragmatist author 
actively participates in what he calls inquiry.

PRAGMATA, 2023-6: 208-252Within the social and human sciences, economics is undoubtedly the discipline that has pushed the rational approach to human behavior the furthest. In orthodox or dominant economic analysis ("the elephant" according to Tomer, 2007), individuals are described as "rational" in the sense that, in the most general sense, they maximize their interests by respecting the constraints (budget or cost) they face.

In orthodox or dominant economic analysis ("the elephant" according to Tomer, 2007), individuals are described as "rational" in the sense that, in the most general sense, they maximize their interests by respecting the constraints (budget or cost) they face. The rational individual is also considered to be someone who constantly minimizes his efforts (work necessarily producing disutility), always seeking to do as little as possible and, 
consequently, having to be stimulated by incentives of all kinds (taxation, penalties, subsidies, etc.). To achieve his 
objectives, homo economicus has exceptional faculties that allow him to make an optimal decision. Homo economicus is in particular a born calculator, endowed with a prodigious memory and a surprising capacity for attention.

Homo economicus is in particular a born calculator, endowed with a prodigious memory and a surprising capacity for attention. Homo economicus 
is also considered self-sufficient, he has full free will 
and perfect self-control. He is endowed with a "theory of mind" 
enabling him to understand the rational behavior of others 
and to adapt to it accordingly. The figure of homo economicus has been progressively “revised” since the 1950s.

The figure of homo economicus has been progressively “revised” since the 1950s. Herbert Simon, then Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky, have largely contributed, in the movement of the “cognitive turn”, to shaking the image of a perfectly rational economic agent. By highlighting the existence of multiple heuristics or cognitive biases, these authors have shown that, if one could still refer to a form of rationality, this was most often “limited” by nature. A second, equally important step led economists, from the beginning of the 1990s – and, this time, in the continuity of the “emotional turn” identified by historians (Plamper, 2010) – to integrate emotion into their theoretical corpus (Elster, 1998).Behavioral and experimental economics (Serra, 2112017) played a major role here.

A second, equally important step led economists, from the beginning of the 1990s – and, this time, in the continuity of the “emotional turn” identified by historians (Plamper, 2010) – to integrate emotion into their theoretical corpus (Elster, 1998).Behavioral and experimental economics (Serra, 2112017) played a major role here. Behavioral economics is clearly in the tradition of the dominant theory in economics. It extends it, but also attempts to go beyond it by amending 
the hypothesis of rationality and opening the door to pro-social behaviors such as altruism or cooperation (Tomer, 2007). By 
drawing on the experimental approach of the psychology of emotions, "behavioral" economists have extracted a whole series of results from data produced in the laboratory that have 
fed the construction of a true "economy of emotions" 
(Petit, 2015).

By 
drawing on the experimental approach of the psychology of emotions, "behavioral" economists have extracted a whole series of results from data produced in the laboratory that have 
fed the construction of a true "economy of emotions" 
(Petit, 2015). Emotions such as regret or envy, for example, 
but also guilt or gratitude, have been introduced into the analysis of the behaviors of economic agents. Risk analysis has also integrated a heuristic called “affective,” in order to take into account the subjective dimension associated with a risky situation (Slovic, Finucane & Peters, 2002). More generally, even if economists have favored emotions with a highly cognitive dimension (such as regret), the affective universe has entered significantly into their software for interpreting individual behaviors.

More generally, even if economists have favored emotions with a highly cognitive dimension (such as regret), the affective universe has entered significantly into their software for interpreting individual behaviors. Despite these advances, emotion nevertheless remains a notion that is difficult to manipulate and exploit within a dominant theoretical corpus that postulates a strong form of rationality, even “limited.” Based almost exclusively on a psychological conception of emotion – the “system 1, system 2” articulated by 
Kahneman (2012) and relayed today by many authors – 
behavioral economics schematically introduces emotion in a dual form, in opposition to reason. In the most recent models, emotion most often constitutes a disruptor of rational decision-making.

In the most recent models, emotion most often constitutes a disruptor of rational decision-making. In counterpoint to a scientific literature on emotions – in neurology, philosophy or even anthropology – which today attests to the usefulness and effectiveness of emotion at the time of decision-making, the work of “behavioral” economists therefore remains confined to a very reductive approach to the affective domain (Petit, 2022). We can thus question how to renew or reorient this 
approach to emotion in economics by identifying bridges 
with disciplines that, such as philosophy, offer an original reading of emotion. The philosopher John Dewey (1859-1952) is one of the influential 
authors of the 20th century who proposed an original and powerful theory of emotion.

The philosopher John Dewey (1859-1952) is one of the influential 
authors of the 20th century who proposed an original and powerful theory of emotion. The pragmatist author describes emotion as a central element of the dynamic and continuous transaction process that exists between the organism and its environment. Emotion is an integral part of the investigation process that is at the heart 
of John Dewey's philosophical construction. It is not conceived 
solely from the point of view of the "interiority" of the subject, as 
most often codified in psychology (on which economists rely today).

It is not conceived 
solely from the point of view of the "interiority" of the subject, as 
most often codified in psychology (on which economists rely today). Nor is it situated 
above” the individual, at the collective or societal level, 
as sociological theories of emotion often present (Stets & Turner, 2014; Illouz, 2019). Based on non-duality 
(of the organism with its environment), Dewey’s theory of emotion 
weaves a close link between the individual and society, between 
reason and affect, between the mind and the body. It is by nature at the interface 
between the individual and the institutional context in which the latter 
makes the decision.

It is by nature at the interface 
between the individual and the institutional context in which the latter 
makes the decision. As a result, Dewey’s theory of emotions 
is an important asset for opening up the perspective of economists around emotion by 
situating itself in a process of transactionbetween the individual and his environment. As a first step, one could hypothesize that it is possible to amend the dominant economic theory (including behavioral economics) by introducing Dewey’s theory of emotions into its logic. Even if Dewey’s approach (1922) is based on social psychology, the place given to the individual remains central, which corresponds to the approach of methodological individualism characteristic of standard economic analysis.

Even if Dewey’s approach (1922) is based on social psychology, the place given to the individual remains central, which corresponds to the approach of methodological individualism characteristic of standard economic analysis. Furthermore, consequentialism also allows us to bring the economists’ approach closer to that of the pragmatist approach. For economists, a decision is judged good or bad depending on the consequences it implies for the subject. For Dewey, the correctness of a decision depends on the outcome of the investigation procedure that the subject implements when making the decision.

For Dewey, the correctness of a decision depends on the outcome of the investigation procedure that the subject implements when making the decision. In a certain way, the logic of inquiry, which presents itself as an activity of integration of different activities and cognitive functions coordinated with each other in view of an end, is therefore similar to a form found in rational choice theory. Despite these possible connections, we wish to show in this article that Dewey’s theory of emotions – articulated throughout the pragmatist perspective on action and rationality – invites us to go beyond the dominant paradigm embodied by standard economics. The American pragmatist’s approach to emotion identifies in particular the shortcomings and inadequacies of behavioral theory.

The American pragmatist’s approach to emotion identifies in particular the shortcomings and inadequacies of behavioral theory. More in opposition than in support, it identifies a path leading to an alternative to this paradigm by highlighting the central role of emotion. As we will see, whether we are at the level of the conception of the individual, his need for security, the logic of action or the moral question, Dewey articulates a thought that calls for a profound change in orthodox economic analysis1. The article is organized as follows. We first highlight the major distinctive features of the theory of emotions constructed by John Dewey throughout his long career. We then study how this author’s theory reveals the shortcomings and limits of standard economic theory based on the rationality of actors.214I. A THEORY OF EMOTIONS

I.1. GENEALOGY OF THE CONSTRUCTION 
OF DEWEY’S THEORY

GENEALOGY OF THE CONSTRUCTION 
OF DEWEY’S THEORY In John Dewey, everything (or almost) can be reduced to the notion of “inquiry”. As Madelrieux (2016: 114) points out, the term is 
borrowed from Charles Sanders Peirce "who understood by it any thought activity provoked by a real 'doubt' and ending with the 
fixation of a 'belief'". Doubt ceases when a belief has been 
fixed and an action can result from it.

Doubt ceases when a belief has been 
fixed and an action can result from it. For analytical reasons (while 
retaining the idea that the stages are nested within each other), 
the scheme of the investigation can be presented according to a specific serial 
order. There is, schematically, the phase of doubt 
(with a strongly emotional component) which corresponds to the case where 
what was self-evident until now is subject to an imbalance (for example, the individual 
discovers a theft or is thwarted in his desires by a change in his environment). Next come the phases of observation and identification of the problem (has the door been broken open?) and the formulation of hypotheses (who, apart from me, has a set of keys?).

Next come the phases of observation and identification of the problem (has the door been broken open?) and the formulation of hypotheses (who, apart from me, has a set of keys?). The fourth stage is that of reasoning, that is to say, the study (by deduction) of the possible consequences of the hypotheses put forward. The fifth phase is that of testing the hypothesis: new observations are made to check whether they correspond (or not) to the consequences deduced. As part of the investigationte, emotion plays a central role.

As part of the investigationte, emotion plays a central role. This 
comes from the fact that as soon as the organism (the individual) is 
continuously and dynamically in a process of transaction with its 
environment, the emotion that sets it in motion is associated with 
all the stages of the investigation initiated by the emergence of a problematic situation. This conception of emotion in Dewey has been 
partly neglected in the scientific literature, unlike 215other approaches better identified in the literature, such as those 
proposed by Bain (1859), James (1884), Ribot (1905), Sartre (1938) or 
Halbwachs (1947). Moreover, its conception is the fruit of a long-term work begun in the mid-1890s (Dewey, 
1894, 1895, 1896), then progressively deepened and developed in 
later writings: Human Nature and Conduct (1922); Experience

1894, 1895, 1896), then progressively deepened and developed in 
later writings: Human Nature and Conduct (1922); Experience 
and Nature (1925); Qualitative Thought (1930); Art as Experience 
(1934a); A Common Faith (1934b); The Quest for Certainty (1938a); 
The Formation of Values ​​(1939). The articles that John Dewey published 
on emotions in the 1890s constitute the foundations of a more elaborate 
theory that finds its culmination, according to Whitehouse 
(1978), about forty years later in Art as Experience. According to Quéré (2018), we can therefore distinguish two distinct phases of 
the construction of Dewey's conception of emotion: a so-called "functional" phase and another more linked to its determining role in the investigation.

OF EMOTION 
Dewey (1894, 1895, 1896) initially sketches a functional psychology 
of emotion, combining (while criticizing) the contributions 
of Darwin (1872) and James (1884). As Garrison (2003) and Quéré (2018) have pointed out, we find in Dewey’s earliest writings, and in particular in the articles of 1894 and 1895, the idea that emotion is “a disposition, a mode of conduct, a way of behaving” (Dewey, 1895, EW.4.172) that is “intentional” or that has “intellectual content” (ibid.

As Garrison (2003) and Quéré (2018) have pointed out, we find in Dewey’s earliest writings, and in particular in the articles of 1894 and 1895, the idea that emotion is “a disposition, a mode of conduct, a way of behaving” (Dewey, 1895, EW.4.172) that is “intentional” or that has “intellectual content” (ibid. : 171). Emotion always concerns “something,” it is “about” something. In 
the 1896 article The Reflex Arc Concept in Psychology, Dewey 
then criticizes the notion, described by the reflex arc, that the 
“sensory stimulus is one thing, the central activity, which 
represents the idea, is another, and the motor discharge, which 
represents the act proper, is a third” (Dewey, 1896, EW.5.97).

In 
the 1896 article The Reflex Arc Concept in Psychology, Dewey 
then criticizes the notion, described by the reflex arc, that the 
“sensory stimulus is one thing, the central activity, which 
represents the idea, is another, and the motor discharge, which 
represents the act proper, is a third” (Dewey, 1896, EW.5.97). In 
reality, the sensory stimulus and the motor response do not have 
autonomous or distinct psychic existences. Rather, “they are 
always within a co-ordination and derive their significance solely 
from the part played in maintaining or reconstituting the co-ordination” 
(ibid.: 99). The reflex arc therefore falsely describes a sequence between the 
stimulus, the idea and the action when it is in fact a circuit, a 
loop.

The reflex arc therefore falsely describes a sequence between the 
stimulus, the idea and the action when it is in fact a circuit, a 
loop. Concrete emotional experience is in particular “distributed” over the 
environment and the organism (it is in both) and, like any vital 
activity, it represents a transaction of a temporal and serial nature. Dewey therefore insists on the fact that emotion has an intentional 
aim whose object is coordination within the organism. Emotion corresponds to a “mode of conduct” (Dewey, 1895, 
EW.4.170), embedded in the investigation, within which the physiological, cognitive and 
affective dimensions must not be dissociated.

Emotion corresponds to a “mode of conduct” (Dewey, 1895, 
EW.4.170), embedded in the investigation, within which the physiological, cognitive and 
affective dimensions must not be dissociated. It is 
possible, as we have mentioned, to distinguish stages of 
the investigation but this "is in reality an intellectual circuit and not 
an "arc"" Madelrieux (2016: 119). I.1.2. EMOTION, AN ESSENTIAL DIMENSION 
OF THE INVESTIGATION In the continuity of this initial work, but also by moving away from a purely functional psychological conception,Dewey

In the continuity of this initial work, but also by moving away from a purely functional psychological conception,Dewey 
(1934a) examines the fundamental place of emotion (and its quality) during experience. Emotion, in its entirety, always corresponds to a mode of conduct, but it represents above all, 
as we will see later, the driving force that guides the experience. Moreover, as Quéré (2018) highlights, while, 
in the articles of 1894 and 1895, emotion is the behavioral manifestation of a “divided activity” (Dewey, 1894, EW.4.156), in 
Art as Experience (1934a) it usefully contributes to the accomplishment of the process of inquiry born of a “problematic situation”, 
and is an integral part of it. To simplify, emotion is one of the 
preferred drivers of inquiry.

To simplify, emotion is one of the 
preferred drivers of inquiry. 217Spread throughout a plethora of works, emotion is a concept in Dewey that has benefited from the insights of biology (it is inspired by Charles Darwin), psychology (it starts from and extends the theory of William James), philosophy (Hegel’s idealism in particular), and then anthropology (Franz Boas, Bronislaw Malinovski). 2 In his many works, Dewey used quite different terms to evoke the emotional process – “instinct” and “reflex” (impulse), but also “feeling”, “emotional energy”, or even “mood” – at the risk of sometimes creating a certain confusion in the reader (Hohr, 2010).

In his many works, Dewey used quite different terms to evoke the emotional process – “instinct” and “reflex” (impulse), but also “feeling”, “emotional energy”, or even “mood” – at the risk of sometimes creating a certain confusion in the reader (Hohr, 2010). In Human Nature and Conduct (1922), a work that deals most extensively with habits, the term “reflex,” or even instinct, appears most often, and not the more common term today of emotion. Hodgson (2007: 127) points out in particular that when writing this work on human nature published in 1922, Dewey was reluctant to use the term instinct (discredited at the time by the behaviorist movement) and that he frequently replaced it with “reflex” (“impulse”). Dewey (1922: 105) himself acknowledges in a footnote the “equivalence” between these two terms and justifies the use of the term reflex.

Dewey (1922: 105) himself acknowledges in a footnote the “equivalence” between these two terms and justifies the use of the term reflex. Yet, as Hohr (2013: 259) points out in a footnote, instinct (in the Freudian sense) is ultimately very close to Dewey’s conception of emotion within experience. The central difference, however, is that in the Freudian individual, the person reacts to a disruption with anxiety, whereas in Dewey, as we will see later, the person is constantly seeking to restore his or her internal balance. The notion of reflex is in fact closely linked to emotion and in a “dialectical” or “transactional” link (Testa, 2017: 8) with the concept of habit.

The notion of reflex is in fact closely linked to emotion and in a “dialectical” or “transactional” link (Testa, 2017: 8) with the concept of habit. In valuation theory, Dewey (1939) rarely uses the term emotion but rather “impulse” or reflex. He explains this at the very end of this text by recalling that,
by describing the valuation and the question of moral values, he wants
to emphasize the limits of the emotivist theory of the time (characterized in particular by the work of Alfred Ayer (1936)). However, 218as we will see, moral inquiry mobilizes reasoning as much as emotion.

However, 218as we will see, moral inquiry mobilizes reasoning as much as emotion. I.1.3. A MODERN CONCEPTION OF EMOTION
Many authors have recently contributed to reassessing and 
resituating Dewey’s contribution to the question of emotion (Garrison, 
2003; Tiles, 2003; Garreta, 2007; Mendonça, 2012; Morse, 2010; 
Hohr, 2010, 2013; Pappas, 2016; Madelrieux, 2016; Crippen, 2018; 
Quéré, 2018, 2021). Dewey’s analysis is very valuable because it accounts for the different stages contained in the emotional process, conceived as a continuous and dynamic activity: in this sense, it is a valuable tool for unifying theories from different academic disciplines (psychology, sociology, biology, philosophy, neuroscience, etc.) around emotion (Mendonça, 2012).e suggests Mendonça, an explicit link can be made
between Dewey and Damasio’s neurological conception of emotion (1995) – the famous “somatic markers” –, a conception that has been 
relayed in many disciplines at the beginning of the 21st century.

between Dewey and Damasio’s neurological conception of emotion (1995) – the famous “somatic markers” –, a conception that has been 
relayed in many disciplines at the beginning of the 21st century. In the pragmatist author, emotions are not considered as autonomous, isolated or purely internal phenomena, 
as most psychological theories of emotion presuppose. They do not correspond to an “immediate discharge” 
(Dewey, 1934a/2005: 263) of an affect and are not “uncontrolled explosions of a disturbed young child” (ibid.: 90).

90). They are not 
universal, but, much more, associated with a specific situation and a particular relationship. As Dewey points out, 
emotion in the ordinary sense of the term is provoked by certain 
objects, physical and personal; it is a response to an objective situation. It is not something that exists somewhere 
in itself and mobilizes materials through which to express itself.

It is not something that exists somewhere 
in itself and mobilizes materials through which to express itself. Emotion indicates an intimate participation, sometimes lively, 219sometimes calmer, in certain natural or existential situations. (Dewey, 1925/2012: 353-354) More precisely, emotions (when they have meaning) are “attributes of a complex experience that progresses and evolves” (Dewey, 
1934a/2005: 90).

More precisely, emotions (when they have meaning) are “attributes of a complex experience that progresses and evolves” (Dewey, 
1934a/2005: 90). Emotions are both the origin of experience 
and also effective operating modes of its unfolding and 
result. Emotion plays a key role, in particular, during the experience, in 
changing our habits of being, thinking or doing. According to 
Dewey, habits must change when they no longer respond 
effectively to the problematic and changing situation that the organism 
is confronted with.

According to 
Dewey, habits must change when they no longer respond 
effectively to the problematic and changing situation that the organism 
is confronted with. This may in particular be a conflict between 
antagonistic habits. In this case, reason alone cannot produce this change, 
because a prerequisite is that the discord is perceived, 
felt, by the individual: "a problem must be felt before it 
can be stated." (Dewey, 1938a/2014: 70 f.).

(Dewey, 1938a/2014: 70 f.). Once the discord 
is perceived, emotion also plays a driving role in the conduct of the 
investigation that allows the unity between the environment and the 
organism to be reestablished. We will look at these two points in turn. I.2.

I.2. EMOTION, AN EFFECTIVE GUIDE 
TO THE CONDUCT OF THE INVESTIGATION
Emotion therefore initially plays a role in “signalling” the crisis, 
the “problematic situation” that the organism is confronted with. Initially in a primary form, it mobilizes us and makes us 
feel that a response must be given to the difficulty encountered by 
our usual behavior. To be moved is first of all to be confronted 
with a situation that leads the individual to improvise a response.

To be moved is first of all to be confronted 
with a situation that leads the individual to improvise a response. Etymologically, the characteristic of emotion (from the Latin “emovere”) is 
to “set us in motion”. In particular, “[e]motion 
is the conscious sign of a current or imminent rupture” (Dewey, 
1934a/2005: 48). From this point of view, it marks the interruption of a 220habit, of a routine.

From this point of view, it marks the interruption of a 220habit, of a routine. It consists of a new modality of 
behavior induced by a form of temporary tension and hesitation 
associated with the activity in progress. "This disagreement engenders 
reflection. The desire to reestablish a union converts pure and 
simple emotion into interest in the objects considered as the conditions 
for achieving harmony."

The desire to reestablish a union converts pure and 
simple emotion into interest in the objects considered as the conditions 
for achieving harmony." (Ibid.) . Faced with a problematic situation, 
emotion therefore provokes investigation. It is at the origin 
of the experience and the change that is required.

It is at the origin 
of the experience and the change that is required. More than a signal, emotions are also 
"pivots", "guides" that provide direction for the reconfiguration of old habits: 
precisely, emotions are "the pivots around which the reorganization of 
activities is articulated, they are adeviation agencies that allow old habits to be given new directions and to change their quality” (Dewey, 1922: 93). They become crucial when the organism tends to act in a certain way in a particular situation, but does not have the resources to do so. Previous habits cease to be adapted to the present situation: action is hindered or constrained.

Previous habits cease to be adapted to the present situation: action is hindered or constrained. In this case, according to the terms of the transactional approach, it is both the environment (as it is objectively) and the way in which the individual adapts to it that are subject to revision. Old habits then disintegrate upon contact with contradictory impulses: emotion is “a source, an indispensable source, of liberation; but it is only when it is used to 
give habits relevance and novelty that it exercises this power" (ibid.: 105). Emotion is therefore both a driving force and a 
cohesive element of the investigation.

Emotion is therefore both a driving force and a 
cohesive element of the investigation. "It selects what accords 
and colors what it has selected with its own hue, thus giving 
qualitative unity to externally disparate and dissimilar materials." (Dewey, 1934a/2005: 92). Emotion appears here as a 
factor of completeness and unity in experience (Quéré, 2018).

Emotion appears here as a 
factor of completeness and unity in experience (Quéré, 2018). "It is emotion that allows one to find the right word, the appropriate incident 
at the appropriate moment, the exquisite harmony of proportions, tone, 
hue, or exact nuance. » (Dewey, 1934a/2005: 134).221During this transactional process, involving habits (old and new), emotion is also the object of an alteration, of its own dynamics. As Garrison (2019: 307) points out, “[i]n his theory of emotion, Dewey carefully distinguishes between vague anoetic feelings4 and emotions such as desire that have a conceptual content in the sense that they have a real or imaginary teleological object.”

As Garrison (2019: 307) points out, “[i]n his theory of emotion, Dewey carefully distinguishes between vague anoetic feelings4 and emotions such as desire that have a conceptual content in the sense that they have a real or imaginary teleological object.” The original, primary, rudimentary and imprecise emotion, born of “suspense,” intrigue and uncertainty, is itself intended to transform itself during the process of resolving the crisis. In Art as Experience, 
Dewey gives an illuminating example of the emotional dynamic, 
a dynamic that opposes routine and creative habit: Two men meet: one of them is applying for a job, 
while the other has the power to decide whether to hire him.

Two men meet: one of them is applying for a job, 
while the other has the power to decide whether to hire him. The 
interview may be mechanical, consisting of a series of standard questions 
[…] There is no experience in which the two men meet, 
and no element that is not a repetition, in the form of agreement 
or refusal, of something that has happened many times […] Yet there may be an interaction that allows a new experience to 
develop .

Yet there may be an interaction that allows a new experience to 
develop . […] The primary emotion on the part of the applicant 
may initially be hope or despair, and at the end elation or 
disappointment. These emotions give unity to the experience. But as the interview progresses, secondary emotions develop, as do variations in the underlying primary emotion.

But as the interview progresses, secondary emotions develop, as do variations in the underlying primary emotion. It is even possible for every attitude, every gesture, every sentence, and almost every word to express an emotion that is more than a simple fluctuation of the primary emotion; that is, a change of nuance and hue in its quality. The employer sees the candidate’s character in the light of his own emotional reactions. He projects him in his imagination into the job for which he is applying and judges his competence according to the way in which the elements of the scene come together, colliding or, on the contrary, adjusting.

He projects him in his imagination into the job for which he is applying and judges his competence according to the way in which the elements of the scene come together, colliding or, on the contrary, adjusting. (Dewey, 1934a/2005: 
92-93; our emphasis) In this example, Dewey differentiates between routine conduct (mechanical maintenance) and what coulderger, at the end of an experience, as an “intelligent”, “sensitive” or “flexible” habit. It also shows the transactional emotional dynamics that 
can lead (or not) to the creation of a new habit and a new 
behavior.

It also shows the transactional emotional dynamics that 
can lead (or not) to the creation of a new habit and a new 
behavior. An experience is therefore intended to modify a 
habit, a way of thinking, being or behaving, when 
it is unsuitable. The individual then confronts highly 
organized habits with “impulses” that are not. These moments 
of tension reveal a permanent movement of ebb and flow.

These moments 
of tension reveal a permanent movement of ebb and flow. Emotion plays a role in the effective reconfiguration of individual habits. Emotion is therefore what allows us to break with the habit. I.3.

I.3. UNITY OF EXPERIENCE 
AND QUALITY OF EMOTION 
Dewey’s adaptive scenario allows, via emotions, the resolution of the conflict between antagonistic individual habits. The resulting return to balance is, however, far from obvious and systematic. If many authors have emphasized that the construction of habits can itself be associated with an “art” (Testa, 2017), or that the experience itself comes from the “sublime” (Gilmore, 2002), it is because the harmonious conduct of habit corresponds to an “ideal” or “intelligent” conduct: “habit is a capacity, an art, formed by past experience.”

In this article, we have attempted to explore the advantages that John Dewey’s
philosophical theory of emotion could confer on traditional economic analysis. Based on a psychological reading of emotion, anchored since its origins on a strong postulate of rationality, economic science tends to (de)consider affect and to systematically place it in opposition to reason. Dewey’s contribution consists precisely in deconstructing this duality by starting from the method of inquiry and by placing emotion245at the center of this process. exist between a dominant economic approach (which integrates 
the economics of behavior) and the pragmatist approach.

exist between a dominant economic approach (which integrates 
the economics of behavior) and the pragmatist approach. One of the 
key advantages of John Dewey’s approach to emotion is to 
highlight the limits of the standard paradigm and consequently suggest going 
beyond it. Where the behavioral economics of emotions offers an 
eruptive, uncontrolled and static reading of individual emotion, Dewey

Dewey’s philosophy invites economists to think about how individuals can learn to educate their emotions in order to enlighten and guide their decision-making.
